author: maraschmiedt6542
content:
> However, if signing power is concentrated amongst a few exchanges -- which we seem to be encouraging with SSVs -- I fear this model breaks down, and fraud proofs will most certainly be required to keep that power in check.
> 
> Why? In a sense, SSVs add more insurance against the behaviour of centralised actors. And this will lead to more people using centralised actors because the insurance makes it safer... **We may well be helping to create a world in which a cartel of 5 exchanges controls > 2/3 of all validators. Would we be happy with that outcome?**

There is and will be an addressable market for centralized providers so long as staking requires a minimum amount of technical literacy and providers are able to offer value-added and tangental services with a convenience factor. 

The majority of folks who plan to stake with a provider (1/3 of all respondents we asked in a study) already hold a big chunk of their eth on centralized exchanges - it's a sticky business and market shares are concentrated. 

SSVs will likely have a stronger impact on decentralizing the signing power of the leading 1-2 providers (e.g. through relative inclusion of smaller providers that may be favourable for anti-correlation strategies), compared to the aggregate traction that enhanced insurance via SSVs will have on those 5+ providers IMO.

On that note, would like to re-highlight this comment by <@!550420431744794624>. Fully agree that it will be critical to surface and communicate the role SSVs may have on failure prevention to a problem space that extends far beyond centralized providers.
